stream_context.summary: Kaze spends the majority of the stream building and debugging Course 14, a cardboard-box themed stage in Return to Yoshi’s Island. The core focus is designing a believable “tape-pull” mechanic that opens the box and drops Mario into a fiery hell section, while fixing a Bowser-holding bug and improving N64 performance.

development_findings.summary: Course 14’s main gimmick will be opening a giant cardboard box; Kaze abandons an earlier zipper idea (from Biobak) and shifts to an animated strip of packing tape that Mario pulls to rip the box open.
development_findings.quote: I think a piece of tape you can pull might actually be better and more fitting instead of a zipper.

development_findings.summary: Technical plan: the tape will be a single animated actor made of multiple very thin segments so the strip can extend without heavy rendering cost; animation timing is being tuned for consistent pull speed.
Inside the box is a red-glowing hell area; Kaze previews the fall sequence and is adding emissive ‘evil glow’ materials to sell the effect.
development_findings.quote: This is gonna look so good once it works … really look like you're falling down into hell.

development_findings.summary: Course 14 performance was poor because every object had infinite draw distance; Kaze reduced draw distance and merged mountain decals into one material, resulting in acceptable framerates.
development_findings.quote: The reason it ran poorly is because … I still had the drawing distance for everything set at infinite.

development_findings.summary: A new HD Mario model is in test: higher-resolution textures, 3-D buttons, shoe detail, and a jiggle-bone nose, yet uses fewer triangles than standard SM64.
development_findings.quote: He also has new features like his nose jiggles … and the buttons are now 3D models.

development_findings.summary: 45 optional ‘Yoshi Star’ comet-style missions are planned; they add challenge conditions (e.g., two or fewer A presses) and are not in the upcoming demo.
development_findings.quote: Instead of a comet appearing there’s going to be a Yoshi that gives you a mission … I’m planning 45 of those in total.

development_findings.summary: A Bowser-holding bug surfaced only in Project 64; action_arc was being overwritten to 0 each frame. Kaze fixed it by switching logic to action_state.
development_findings.quote: They really just use action arc and action state interchangeably; that’s weird … so I changed it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze says Germany is among his ‘top 10 worst countries to live in’; he now resides in Canada.
context_findings.quote: Germany is the worst country to live in in the entire world.

context_findings.summary: He actively optimizes Twitter for ad-revenue and recently hit 250 k monetized impressions, calling it ‘making a hell of a bank.’
context_findings.quote: The Twitter monetization grind is going way better than I thought. We hit 250k today … yes, we’re making a hell of a bank on Twitter.

context_findings.summary: He rejects click-baity YouTube titles like ‘The Secret Reason’ as too cringe, preferring straightforward framing for an upcoming video about rewriting Mario 64.
context_findings.quote: Calling it ‘the secret reason’ is just too cringe. I can’t do it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans daily streams this week and intends to include his workout live, indicating a blend of personal routine and dev work.
context_findings.quote: I do have the whole week off so I'm probably streaming basically every day … but I will have to do my workout on stream.

biobak.summary: Suggested an initial zipper mechanism for the box; provided reference images Kaze later reopened while modeling.
Engages with Kaze on social media strategy and word-game side conversations; described by Kaze as someone who would ‘min-max’ Twitter impressions or play any Wordle clone he makes.
biobak.quote: True, Biobak, but Twitter impressions are something we min-max.

zeina.summary: Zeina had friends over during the stream, requiring Kaze to finish by 5 PM; no direct development input this session.

key_stories.title: Choosing Tape over Zipper
key_stories.summary: The box-opening mechanic began as a zipper (Biobak’s idea), but Kaze felt it clashed with the cardboard motif. After weighing vertex animation costs and visual fit, he pivoted to a pullable tape strip.
key_stories.challenge: Create a believable, low-poly way for Mario to open a giant cardboard box.
key_stories.process: Brainstormed zipper, staples, knife, then animated tape; evaluated rendering cost and gameplay clarity.
key_stories.outcome: Settled on a segmented ‘packing tape’ actor that Mario grabs and pulls, triggering the box flap to open.
key_stories.key_quote: A zipper feels so unfitting … a piece of tape you can pull might actually be better.

key_stories.title: The Bowser Hold Bug
key_stories.summary: While testing Course 14, Mario randomly dropped Bowser only in Project 64. Debugging revealed the engine inadvertently reset action_arc to 0 every frame.
key_stories.challenge: Unexplained Bowser release differing between emulators.
key_stories.process: Compared Nemu vs. Project 64, set breakpoints on action_arc, traced writes, found legacy code using arc/state interchangeably.
key_stories.outcome: Patched logic to use action_state, eliminating the bug.
key_stories.key_quote: They really just use action arc and action state interchangeably; that’s weird … so I changed it.

key_stories.title: The Performance Scare
key_stories.summary: Early tests of Course 14 lagged badly; investigation showed all objects inherited an ‘infinite’ draw distance from a previous project.
key_stories.challenge: Severe framerate drops in the new level.
key_stories.process: Identified infinite draw distance, reduced it, merged mountains into one material and adjusted decals.
key_stories.outcome: Stage now runs ‘mostly fine,’ freeing headroom for additional effects.
key_stories.key_quote: The stage runs poorly because … I still had the drawing distance for everything set at infinite.
